awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Understanding At-Risk Adolescents' and Parents' Daily Experiences During COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
While the COVID-19 pandemic has far-reaching effects on communities and individuals, its impact on at-risk youth may be particularly pervasive and distinct. This RAPID project will study how at-risk adolescents and their parents experience COVID-19 in the initial time period following the novel coronavirus pandemic. The research will compare adolescents’ sleep, social skills, social relationship quality, stress, mood, substance use, mental health symptoms, physical health, psychosocial development, externalizing behavior, and delinquency across the COVID-19 outbreak. The project also will examine whether juvenile incarceration exacerbates the potential impact of COVID-19 on youth outcomes. 

The project will engage in a longitudinal study of at-risk (justice-involved, low-SES) adolescents to address how adolescent-parent dyads respond to and are affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. This research will use multiple methods, including self-report, collateral report, official records from the partnering department of probation, electronic daily diary reports, and actigraph technology, to assess changes in adolescents’ and parents’ functioning on a variety of outcomes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The findings will evince physical and mental health risks in response to the pandemic among at-risk youth. As well, the research will provide best practices for juvenile detention facilities and departments of probation in times of crises to ensure that youth continue to receive important rehabilitative services while maintaining the health and safety of youth, legal actors, and community members. Results will contribute to the limited existing knowledge base on the needs, risks, and potential protective factors of a vulnerable group of youth during a global state of emergency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined adolescents’ and parents’ experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic in a large southwestern city on the United States-Mexico border (El Paso, TX). A total of 104 adolescents and 92 parent participants took part in at least one timepoint of this longitudinal, three-wave study. Participants came from a larger, ongoing longitudinal study that began prior to the pandemic; participants were recruited from three distinct subgroups: adolescents incarcerated to a 9-month secure residential program at the local juvenile justice facility, adolescents on community probation in a 9-month program, and never-arrested adolescents from the community. Participants were largely Hispanic or Latino, reflecting the ethnic make-up of the city.  The study included three waves of interview data covering one year of the pandemic. Additionally, the study included six weeks of twice-daily electronic daily diary surveys, as well as actigraph assessments to evaluate sleep quantity and quality (each week of data collection was administered bimonthly across one year).


Three publications emerged from this work at the time of this report:


The first paper examined factors associated with adolescents’ adherence to health guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) early in the pandemic. Findings revealed that adolescents who were more psychosocially mature (i.e., less impulsive, better at thinking toward the future, more autonomous in their thinking and behavior, better able to suppress their aggression and manage their emotions) were more likely to follow the health guidelines than their less mature counterparts. Further, more mature adolescents were more likely to report feeling it was important to follow the guidelines, which partially explained their greater adherence behavior compared to less mature adolescents. 


The second paper explored adolescents’ concerns about COVID-19 across three key domains of interest: economic/financial, social, and COVID-19 health concerns. Group differences between adolescents from the three groups (incarcerated, on probation, and never arrested community adolescents) were explored. With respect to economic concerns, incarcerated youth felt more concern about their ability to get a job if needed than youth on probation or community youth, and more concerned about food security. With respect to social concerns, both incarcerated youth and youth on probation felt that the quality of their relationship with family members had decreased as a result of the pandemic, relative to community youth, while incarcerated youth only felt that the quality of their friendships had decreased. With respect to concerns about COVID-19, no group differences were observed about getting sick or dying from COVID-19, but low-income youth regardless of justice system status were more concerned about dying of COVID-19 than their affluent counterparts. Overall, the study gives voice to the concerns of the most vulnerable youth during the pandemic.


Finally, the last study was conducted in conjunction with 11 other studies as part of an international consortium of adolescent-centered COVID-19 research. This study examined to what extent adolescents’ depression and anxiety symptoms changed from prior to COVID-19 to during the first six months of the pandemic in an international sample of 1,339 adolescents. Findings revealed that depression symptoms increased over this period of time, whereas anxiety symptoms remained stable overall. However, these findings varied depending on the race and ethnicity of the adolescent, as well as local case rates and government restriction levels; more negative health impacts were experienced by multiracial adolescents and those under the most intensive restrictions.
